Award.AwardTitle: The Institute for Mathematics and its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Institute for Mathematics and its Applications (IMA) is a visitors' institute whose goals are to (1) develop transformative mathematical research through interdisciplinary exploration, (2) strengthen the workforce that engages in interdisciplinary mathematical research, and (3) provide rapid dissemination of research and promote the mathematical sciences. To achieve these goals, the IMA offers activities involving the mathematical sciences in the broadest sense and encompassing the physical, computer, life, and social sciences, as well as engineering and industry. Through these activities, the IMA works to solidify the role of the mathematical sciences as the foundation for twenty-first century research and technology.

The IMA serves as a hub for collaboration, bringing together mathematical scientists and application domain experts. The annual thematic program focuses either on an application field where mathematics is poised to make important contributions or on a branch of mathematics and its applications. Long-term visitors and postdoctoral fellows form the intellectual anchor of the activity; shorter-term visitors come for week-long workshops on related topics. The IMA is also an established center for industrial mathematics, serving as a resource for industry through joint sponsorship of postdoctoral fellows and workshops in areas of importance to industry. These activities facilitate technology transfer from researchers to industrial users.

IMA programs provide research training for postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates. The IMA also offers educational activities designed to engage future scientists of high-school age and beyond. The IMA vigorously pursues the engagement of under-represented groups in the mathematical sciences and also runs workshops directly addressing diversity in the mathematical sciences. The Institute runs a public lecture series to increase awareness of, and appreciation for, the role contemporary mathematics plays in the resolution of important technological, scientific, and societal problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is the Project Outcomes Report for award NSF DMS 1440471 from the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications (IMA), covering the period September 1, 2015, to August 31, 2017, and two no-cost extension periods September 1, 2017 to August 31, 2018 and September 1, 2018 - August 31, 2019. The IMA was an NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) Mathematical Sciences Research Institute. Its mission connects scientists, engineers, and mathematicians in order to address scientific and technological challenges in a collaborative, engaging environment, developing transformative, new mathematics and exploring its applications, while training the next generation of researchers and educators. It is located on the campus of the University of Minnesota, and is a partnership between the NSF, University of Minnesota, and affiliated academic institutions and corporations.

The IMA explores a theme in applied mathematics through a series of tutorials, workshops, and seminars. The annual program, lasting 10 months and involving more than 1,000 participants, draws a large and diverse community of participants from academia, industry, and government. The annual themes are broad and timely and aim to advance mathematical research, generate new opportunities, and create lasting impacts in various application areas. Generally, 60 percent of the program's participants are from mathematics departments, and 40 percent are from application fields. Connecting mathematicians with applied scientists in an environment conducive to interdisciplinary collaboration is at the core of the IMA's mission and a major outcome of this yearly program. Two such thematic programs occurred during the grant period: Control Theory and its Applications in 2015-2016, which consisted of seven workshop, more than 1000 long- and short-term visitors, and Mathematics and Optics in 2016-2017, which consisted of five workshops and more than 800 visitors. 

Under a first no-cost extension, during 2017-18, the IMA ran a number of smaller programs selected from an open call for proposals from the research community. These programs hosted a large and broad collection of mathematical researchers. Under the new operating model instituted in 2017, total visits to the IMA remained very robust (1407 total visits). The five major programs for this academic year were:

  • Industrial Math Clinic and Workshop,
  • SageMath and OpenKIM (open-source software) coding sprints,
  • Multiscale Mathematics and Computing in Science and Engineering,
  •  Innovative Statistics and Machine Learning in Precision Medicine, and
  • Modeling, Stochastic Control, Optimization, and Related Applications

Workshops during the 2018-19 year supported by the remainder of the no-cost extension include:

  • COIN fORgery: Developing open-source tools for operations research,
  • Recent Advances in Machine Learning and Geosciences,
  • Statistical and Computational Challenges in Precision Medicine,
  • Working groups in modeling of two-dimensional materials,
  • Mathematics in Optical Imaging, and
  • Biology, Analysis, Geometry, Energies, Links: A Program on Low-dimensional Topology, Geometry, and Applications

Dissemination of results:

The IMA videotapes and live-streams all lectures and discussions during institute activities, at the consent of the presenters. Each taping is permanently archived in the video library. According to Google Analytics data, there were 113,659 views of IMA videos in 2018.

The IMA Volumes in Mathematics and its Applications, now at 163 published, are used to collect papers from highly successful programs and workshops each year. Online download information for these volumes is available from Springer, and shows a range of several thousand to more than 25,000 downloads for each.

The IMA produced six new volumes in the Springer Math series during the period 2015-2019:

  • Applications of Dynamical Systems in Biology and Medicine, T. Jackson and A. Radunskaya (Eds.), Vol.158 (2015).
  • Recent Trends in Combinatorics, A. Beveridge, J.R. Griggs, L. Hogben, G. Musiker, P. Tetali (Eds.),Vol. 159 (2016).
  • Topics in Numerical Partial Differential Equations and Scientific Computing, S. Brenner, (Ed.) Vol.160 (2016).
  • Convexity and Concentration, E. Carlen, M. Madiman, E. Werner, (Eds.), Vol. 161 (2017).
  • Energy Markets and Responsive Grids: Modeling, Control, and Optimization Series, S. Meyn,, T. Samad,I. Hiskens, J. Stoustrup (Eds.), Vol. 162 (2018).
  • Frontiers in PDE-Constrained Optimization, H. Antil, D.P. Kouri,, M.-D. Lacasse, D. Ridzal (Eds.),Vol. 163 (2018).
